pages.text:
â“ŸThough they may gather some Left-wing support, a
large majority of <ORGANISATION>Labour</ORGANISATION> M Ps are likely to
turn down the Foot-Griffiths resolution. Mr.
<PER>Foot's</PER> line will be that as <ORGANISATION>Labour</ORGANISATION> M Ps
opposed the Government Bill which brought
life peers into existence, they should not
now put forward nominees. He believes
that the <ORGANISATION>House of Lords</ORGANISATION> should be abolished
and that <ORGANISATION>Labour</ORGANISATION> should not take any steps
which would appear to " prop up " an out-dated
institution.â“…

National Congress</ORGANISATION> ( <CARDINAL>400,000</CARDINAL> ) will meet in ðŸ—ºLondon</LOCATION> <TIME>today</TIME>

the ðŸ—ºLondon</LOCATION> talks on the Protectorate's

" We want to discuss what to do if the
<ORGANISATION>British Government</ORGANISATION> gives in to Sir <PER>Roy</PER> and
the talks fall through. There are bound
to be demonstrations. " <TIME>Yesterday</TIME> Sir <PER>Roy's</PER>
chief aide, Mr. <PER>Julius Greenfield</PER>, telephoned
his chief a report on his talks with
Mr. <PER>Macmillan</PER> at ðŸ—ºChequers</LOCATION>.â“…

â“ŸMr. <PER>Macleod</PER> went on with the conference at

to the <NORP>Africans</NORP> and <NORP>Liberals</NORP> attending. These

<ORGANISATION>Labour's</ORGANISATION> attack on the higher health
charges. Mr. <PER>Powell</PER>, white-faced and outwardly
unemotional, replied with a statistical state-
ment - and ended by inciting <ORGANISATION>Labour</ORGANISATION> M Ps
to angry uproar. <CARDINAL>One</CARDINAL> dealt with the human
issue behind the <ORGANISATION>Health Service</ORGANISATION>; the other
tried to show that the balance-sheet must
always come <CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL>.â“…

â“ŸHe told them that their conception of social services was wholly
different - fundamentally different from that of <ORGANISATION>Labour</ORGANISATION>. They
would provide an ambulance service for the absolutely
wretched - but it would not be too comfortable nor too easy to
get. Answering jeers that it was <ORGANISATION>Labour</ORGANISATION> which <CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> put a
ceiling on health spending and started charges, Mr. <PER>Brown</PER>
reminded the hostile <ORGANISATION>Government</ORGANISATION> benches that was
done in <TIME>1950</TIME> because of the financial strain of
the <NORP>Korean</NORP> war.â“…

Then Mr. <PER>Brown</PER> swung his attack directly to the
unsmiling Mr. <PER>Powell</PER>. He demanded that instead
of taking it out of the patients Mr. <PER>Powell</PER> should
take ruthless action against the drug making
industry, whose profits had risen by <CARDINAL>up to 400</CARDINAL>
per cent. in <TIME>the last eight years</TIME>.â“…

â“ŸWhen Mr. <PER>Brown</PER> sat down <ORGANISATION>Labour</ORGANISATION> M Ps cheered for
<TIME>a full minute</TIME> - and even his bitterest opponents
on defence joined in. Mr. <PER>Powell</PER> devoted <CARDINAL>half</CARDINAL> his speech
to giving details of plans for improving the hospital service,
on which indeed the <ORGANISATION>Government</ORGANISATION> is making progress.

indication of the scope of <PER>Wicki's</PER> artistry. He
tells his story best in the faces of his crowds,
recording every wrinkle and drop of sweat
with brutal honesty, building up to a
tremendous climax in the island orgy.
Here, the guests arrive in ghost-like yachts,
the wildly flapping white sails slashed by
the glaring beacon of a lighthouse.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸWhen the final miracle does occur, it is accepted as a
marvellous joke; no one has learned anything. <PER>Wicki</PER>
suddenly returns to the city for a final epilogue. In
complete silence he shows the faces of people
walking in the streets, smug, content, satisfied,
and thoroughly frightening. <PER>Wicki</PER> has
succeeded in his <CARDINAL>second</CARDINAL> film in
recording his personal apocalypse of the
<TIME>last days</TIME> of a sick society.â“…

in " Titanic " by paralleling the <TIME>last days</TIME> of the
ðŸ—ºThird Reich</LOCATION> with the sinking of the great ocean liner,
and paid for his audacity with his life.â“…

â“ŸStrangely enough, the ðŸ—ºBerlin</LOCATION> audience received
the film with extreme coolness, much preferring
<PER>Jean-Luc Godard's</PER> disappointing " Une Femme
est une Femme, " a <TIME>ninety-one minute</TIME> hymn
to " <ORGANISATION>Vogue</ORGANISATION>, " " Cahiers du Cinema, " and the
worst aspects of the <NORP>American</NORP> cinema. From
a brilliantly funny start, the work fizzles
out into a series of repetitious sight-gags
and personal jokes incomprehensible to the
uninitiated ( including <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> plugs for <PER>Charles
Aznavour</PER> ).â“…

â“ŸThis director is at last being re-evaluated and
given his proper place in the history of the
<NORP>German</NORP> film. Most charming was his tongue-in-cheek
" Unheimliche Geschichten " ( <TIME>1920</TIME> ), <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> ghost stories
with a light touch, and there was much to admire
in " Dreyfus " ( <TIME>1930</TIME> ) and the virtually unknown
but extremely important " <TIME>1914</TIME> " ( <TIME>1931</TIME> ), which
tries to show that it took more than just
ðŸ—ºGermany</LOCATION> to start the <CARDINAL>First</CARDINAL> World War.â“…

â“ŸSentence Database C02-059
Prizes being what they are, ðŸ—ºBerlin</LOCATION> is unusually
generous in giving everyone something, and silver
bears are awarded in every direction. Both the
<PER>Antonioni</PER> and <PER>Wicki</PER> films took high honours,
and the audience at the awards was particularly
enthusiastic when one Miss <PER>Anna Kerima</PER> was selected
as best actress for her work in the <PER>Godard</PER>
film. Gifted with an interesting face, although little
acting ability, she would seem to be well
worth watching in the <TIME>months to come</TIME>.â“…

â“ŸIt has a great look of speed and technical fun
about it, of enormous cinematic enjoyment, and
above all of cinematic sense. Much of it has
that air of improvisation, as of off-the-cuff
living, that once seemed so new and so
attractive. The story ( not that the story, in the
sense of plot, matters much; but in the sense of
situation and movement it matters a lot ) is
that of a man on the run ( <PER>Jean-Paul Belmondo</PER> ),
who spends <TIME>a few days</TIME> with an <NORP>American</NORP> girlâ“…

â“ŸThis is not a filmed play. It has been
conceived throughout in terms of the cinema,
and again and again it is the visual qualities
of the story, and the marriage of the central
characters to their background, which bring
the film so vividly to life. In Fanny, which
also has its premiere <TIME>tomorrow</TIME>, the director,
Mr. <PER>Joshua Logan</PER>, attempted but failed to create
the atmosphere of a city.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸBut there is heart in the telling, and an
intense realism in the situation. A young
girl lives in a single dingy room with
her slatternly, promiscuous mother. In such
surroundings she learns sex is something
sordid, and when she experiences it for the
<CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> time herself it is incoherently, clumsily,
but <CARDINAL>half</CARDINAL> inquisitively. As is the case in Fanny
her <CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> lover is a sailor who leaves her
to bear his child and sails away.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸIn Fanny the pregnant girl is befriended by
an old man. Here it is a young homosexual,
estranged from women but yet moved by a
strong maternal instinct to the unborn child
as much as to the expectant mother, who acts
as a protector and comforter to her in her
hour of need. He shares her room and gives
her his forlorn gift of companionship and sym-
pathy - " you need someone to love you while
you are looking for someone to love ".â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸArguably, the dramatist has committed a
technical error in allowing <PER>Irene</PER> to speak
for herself; we would be altogether clearer
in our minds about her if she remained
a flawed but beautiful enigma, seen but not
heard. However, Miss <PER>Pinkie Johnstone</PER> makes her
few brief scenes effective, and Mr. <PER>Dinsdale
Landen</PER>, in the longest and most exacting role,
that of the sergeant, gives a performance of
rare intelligence and restrained power.â“…

â“ŸMr. <PER>Bryan Stonehouse's</PER> production is quietly
effective, giving full value to the formal elements
of <PER>Betti's</PER> writing without over-emphasizing
them. <TIME>Last night's</TIME> play in the " Play of the
Week " series on independent television, Then
We Fall, by Mr. <PER>Paul Ferris</PER>, was a morality
on the not unfamiliar theme of the destructive
power of unbridled ambition.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸIt went, perhaps, some distance beyond most
treatments of its subject by attempting to
generate a melodramatic inevitability which
left its central character and the world
around him in complete, unredeemable desolation.
We could, perhaps, say whether or not the attempt
succeeded if we had a little more faith in the
way in which Mr. <PER>Ferris</PER> manipulated his
characters.â“…

with which he had endowed them. One
hopes that he is not asking us to believe
that, because of their odd accents, they
act oddly like the queer foreigners of
tradition.â“…

scene where <CARDINAL>six</CARDINAL> of the cast changed

get it into your head, son... people

pages.text:
â“ŸBut lace-making is by no means a lost
art. It suffered a decline and fell into
lamentably low standards in the fussy
over-furnishing of the <TIME>Victorian age</TIME>
but it would take more than a temporary
lapse in good taste to destroy this lovely,
viable craft. It has, in fact, readily
adapted itself to modern tastes and the ill-
ustrations in the following pages will show
how completely it is in sympathy with con-
temporary surroundings.â“…

and rich colour, knitting, crochet and
tatting in fine and medium-weight cottons
can give striking individuality to many things
in the home. Chairbacks, cushions, tablecloths,
to mention only <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> - how satisfying it is
to avoid the ready-made in these and by
one's own handiwork produce something
that reflects true creative talent.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThe more delicate patterns and finer
threads may be reserved to bring a light
and lovely touch to personal possessions -
a lace border to a handkerchief, fine-lace
insertion on a petticoat or blouse, a tatted edge
to a collar; these add a charming, feminine
distinction that nothing else can give.
Although we assess lace-making as <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> of
the feminine skills, a number of the well-loved
traditional patterns that we follow <TIME>today</TIME> were,
in fact, the brain-children of inventive men.â“…

boys as well. Whole families made their
livelihood by lace-making and consequently
a folklore of song, festival and courtship grew
up around the lace industry.â“…

tablecloths, traycloths and runners, and edgings
from heavy to fine can fulfil a variety of
functions. The art of crochet is not difficult and
it is reasonably quick to work. In the following
pages simple diagrams and instructions are given
to enable the beginner to master all the essential
crochet stitches.â“…

on the linen following the outline of the crochet edges
which are to be attached to the linen. Remove crochet.â“…

pages.text:
â“Ÿ<CARDINAL>Two</CARDINAL> methods can be used to join the crochet to the linen:
( a ) Button Stitch round the outline of basting stitches,
the knotted part of the button stitch lying on the
outside edge. Oversew crochet to button stitch.
( b ) Turn under a small hem, with fold lying on line
of basting stitches. Work a row of dc all round
this hem, with <CARDINAL>3</CARDINAL> dc at each corner.â“…

â“ŸRemember that texture plays an important part in
the beauty of crochet. The finer mercerised threads
are more effective for the delicate designs used for
tablecloths, doilies, edgings and accessories, while
the heavier threads are used for bedspreads,
chairbacks, luncheon mats, etc. Crochet hooks
are made of steel, composition or bone. Steel
crochet hooks range in size from number <CARDINAL>3/0</CARDINAL>,
the largest, to number <CARDINAL>8</CARDINAL>, the smallest.â“…

legs, and in reproduction period pieces they
are frequently used. The simpler varieties are
extremely easy to work, the <CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> sides being
simply planed to give the required taper. In
the more elaborate varieties, however, a toe is
worked in the solid, and this certainly
complicates the operation.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸBut why woodwork in particular ? Well, there
are many reasons. Wood is in good and
common supply; it lends itself to making
innumerable useful household items -
furniture, fitments, garden items, toys, etc.;
it enables results to be obtained fairly
quickly; it is less expensive than most
other materials; it is a pleasant material
to work with; and, although it does
create a certain amount of mess, it is
all clean and easily cleared away.â“…

everyone has come to recognise that machines
are not only an economic necessity, but that a
great deal of drudgery can be avoided by the
installation of a power tool. As an elementary
example, surely no one can pretend to enjoy
ripping out parts from hardwood. Most men
would unhesitatingly use a machine if it
were available.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸComing now to the actual tools and their cost, we begin
with what we have called a bare minimum kit. Probably
most men have some of the tools already. It will enable
a man to make simple, straight-forward things, and in
any case may be regarded as a good beginning to
which other tools can be added as the need arises. The
nature of the work will probably dictate the additions
to be made, but as a guide we have given a fuller kit
which increases the range of things that can be
made enormously.â“…

certain special tools will become

pages.text:
â“ŸMost tools have to lead an intensive life, and faults
in design or quality soon become apparent. It is far
better to pay the fair price for a tool of good
quality, and not handicap yourself from the start.
To put it in a slightly different way, do not allow
yourself to blame the tools when the job does
not turn out quite right !â“…

â“ŸMany men with only limited accommodation
have to do their woodwork on the kitchen table.
Providing this is sound, some perfectly good
work can be done on it, but the usual problems
are those of the vice, the bench stop, and storage
place for tools. The combined bench top and
tool cupboard shown here has been specially
designed and made for <ORGANISATION>WOODWORKER</ORGANISATION>
readers who have this difficulty.â“…

a suitable pastel shade, using a contrasting colour
for the seat and the back which can be decorated with
a suitable nursery transfer.â“…

and an outboard motor with a comfortable
margin of freeboard.â“…

is nailed and glued together strongly, it may be marked
and cut to shape later.â“…

correspond to the sides and bottom of the boat.

moulds, which will only be used whilst

pages.text:
â“ŸThe chine is the long stringer on each side which
is joined to both transoms and lies in the grooves
cut in the moulds. Each chine is made of oak,
ash, spruce or any long grained flexible wood. I
prefer spruce when available. As will be seen
in the plan, the transoms have a frame <CARDINAL>1</CARDINAL> in. by <CARDINAL>1</CARDINAL> in.
on each side.â“…

to see that nothing is distorted. Ensure that
the outside measurements from transom to transom
are equal on each side and that the transoms
are parallel horizontally. Next bevel the chines
with a plane so that the bottom will fit snugly.â“…

eating other insects. <CARDINAL>Nine</CARDINAL> blowflies
may be consumed at <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> sitting and
the fully adult, <CARDINAL>2 1/2-in.-long</CARDINAL> insect,
is able to keep a firm hold on <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL>
grasshopper while eating another.
According to Dr. <PER>Max Beier</PER> in " Fang-
heuschrecken " ( Die Neue <PER>Brehm</PER> Bu"ckerei,
<TIME>1952</TIME> ), the praying mantis is trecking
northwards.â“…

brittle nature; even with reasonably careful
handling, the annual losses are often <CARDINAL>around
10</CARDINAL> per cent., and where the handling and
storage facilities are not too good, these
losses will be even greater. This does not
necessarily apply to the larger sizes, as
they are not quite so fragile as the
smaller ones and are not normally thrown
about in quite the same way.â“…

definite disadvantage. They are fairly heavy
and difficult things to accommodate and

weather, which can be quite a headache in
a small garden. While admitting that
broken pots have on occasions provided
artists with delightful studies, there is no
doubt that a pile of badly stacked,
<CARDINAL>half-broken</CARDINAL> pots is an unlovely sight
from any point of view.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸIt is not easy to make an economic
comparison between clay pots and the various
substitutes; the former may last indefinitely
with luck, while the latter are often
expendable used only once. Clay pots are
efficient and congenial containers in which
to grow plants. In their proper setting they
are not unattractive and, in spite of
their shortcomings, most gardeners have
a nostalgic affection for them.â“…

â“ŸPresent-day pots are better finished, do
not get dirty so readily and are easier to
wash. The deep rims make for neater and
safer stacking, though they are still
expensive and still get broken. On the
other hand, there is really no replacement
for the larger sizes, so they have the
decided advantage of being the only
suitable container available in quantity
for fairly large plants.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸSoil blocks are probably the oldest alternative to clay
pots for plant raising. These are compressed blocks of
compost, made in a specially devised press to
simulate roughly the shape and size of a pot.
Usually cylindrical or hexagonal in shape, they
are made of the same compost as would have
been used in a pot, the # only difference being
that it is used in a slightly moister
condition.â“…

pages.text:
â“Ÿ<CARDINAL>One</CARDINAL> big advantage of soil blocks is an obvious
one: the cost of a pot of any description is saved
completely. Manufacturing the block and planting
it is very little more trouble than normal potting,
and a superior plant, which transplants more
easily, is produced. The obvious limitation #
is that soil blocks can only be used for
propagating; there can be no progression to a
larger block when the plant or seedling is ready
to be moved; it must be planted out or
potted.â“…

vocabulary to work on the existing store
so as to make it grow. He does not
simply pack new things into the store.
The solitary learner has to find out
how to do this for himself, with the help
of books. He uses his vocabulary to
ask questions and uses the books to
find the answers.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThus learning how to learn means becoming
your own philosopher, your own psychologist
and your own teacher. You will then be
a well-established learner and the world
will be at your feet. Although the word
" mind " has given rise to endless
controversy among philosophers and psycho-
logists, many of whom would like to
abolish it from the dictionary, most
of us obstinately go on using it.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸAnd then you get a knock on the head and all evidence of
" mind " vanishes, at any rate for some time. It seems very difficult
to detach the mind from the brain, and all the biological,
surgical and pharmacological evidence points to a very
close connection. There is a lot to be said for keeping the
word " soul " to stand for what many believe to be the imperishable
essence of a man which is supposed to persist apart from
the body, and to reserve the more prosaic word " mind " for
the basis of all those experiences and phenomena which
are clearly associated with the brain.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸCan we now put forward any reasonably clear
picture of this " basis " of mental phenomena ?
The physicists have succeeded remarkably well,
with the atomic theory, in giving a clear and detailed
picture of the basis of such material phenomena
as chemical action, magnetism, the behaviour of
gases and so on. Where has psychology got to in its
theories of " mind " ? Are there any ultimate units
of mind akin to the atoms of matter ?â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸAt one time it was thought that mind could indeed
be analysed into discrete bits. These bits were
identified as elementary sensations. These were
thought to combine together to form compound
experiences by analogy with the way atoms of
matter combine to form molecular compounds.
But this view led to too many difficulties and
was finally abandoned. Nevertheless the search
for basic units of mind has gone on and will
doubtless continue, for it is the aim of science to
discover ultimate units.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸWe must beware, however, of supposing that there must be any
close analogy between the units of quite different
sciences. For example the success of the atomic theory
in physics might lead us to suppose that the ultimate
units of geometry must be points. It would be more
correct to regard operations as the ultimate units of
geometry.â“…

we can only indicate what seems to be the most promising

concrete it will be at the cost of over-simplification
but even so it may be better than a meaningless abstraction.â“…

directly look into the mental processes of another
person they observe his visible behaviour and then try
to give theoretical interpretations of what lies behind
this behaviour. This is no more queer than the method
of the doctor who observes signs, and records symptoms,
and diagnoses the inner states responsible for them.â“…

can nevertheless identify it. Similarly the psychologist has
to be prepared to observe and make inferences about
all kinds of processes in other people, whether or not they
correspond with anything in his own experience. We know
very little about the patterns of brain-activity which
provide our schemas, nor do we need to know as far as
psychology is concerned - these patterns are the concern of
the neuro-physiologists.â“…

â“ŸIt was while I was at ðŸ—ºTatsfield</LOCATION> that I <CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> visited ðŸ—ºOberammergau</LOCATION>
in ðŸ—ºBavaria</LOCATION> to witness the Passion Play. The place and its people were
to play an important part in my life. For <TIME>five years</TIME> in succession till
war broke out in <TIME>1914</TIME>, I spent my summer holidays there and became
very intimate with the people and the environs. <TIME>Every year</TIME> between the
Passion Plays, an interval of <TIME>ten years</TIME>, another play would be
performed at the small theatre in the village, when new talent would
be discovered and trained.â“…

pages.text:
â“Ÿ<CARDINAL>First</CARDINAL> of all simple part-songs: I found only <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> member who had
any idea of reading music. This was the village doctor who was an
old school friend at ðŸ—ºClifton</LOCATION>. He could sustain the tenor part quite well
and lead the others. As for basses and altos the conductor had to
teach by singing the parts with them. It was very amusing, and by
the <TIME>end of a few months</TIME> an enthusiastic choir of men and women
could render simple part-singing tolerably well.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThen we went to work on <PER>Coleridge Taylor's</PER> ' <PER>Hiawatha's</PER>
Wedding Feast. ' Enthusiasm grew, and in <TIME>a few more months</TIME> we
gave a concert at which the accompanist was the village schoolmaster,
and the tenor solo ' Onaway awake ' was sung by the Rector.
Friends from ðŸ—ºLimpsfield</LOCATION>, in addition to the villagers, came up,
and we were all happy.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸVery soon we managed to get a hut in ðŸ—ºPurley</LOCATION> where soldiers
were very welcome and the ladies organized a canteen. Life was
in those years more than busy. We now had a vicarage next
to the church, and I was most fortunate in having for <TIME>eight
years</TIME> a most able and devoted housekeeper whom I had known
well in ðŸ—ºLimpsfield</LOCATION> where she had a house next to the
church.â“…

â“ŸOn hearing that I was to leave ðŸ—ºTatsfield</LOCATION> and come to
ðŸ—ºPurley</LOCATION> she offered to come and look after me. She was
a real treasure, of yeoman stock and clever in all domestic
things, a widow who knew how to look after the ' boy, '
who was the only other occupant of the house when
Mr. <PER>Evitt</PER> had gone.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸWe gathered together a splendid <TIME>Sunday
afternoon</TIME> service at the church, each child
being given a number which, as they came into
church, they could just whisper to
the superintendent who filled in the regi-
ster at her own home. Each child had a
picture given them and the lesson was
largely based on this. It was on a
stamp which could be stuck in
their book, and there was quite a
clamour for back stamps if a child
had to miss the <TIME>Sunday</TIME> Church from any causeâ“…

pages.text:
â“ŸIt was quite amusing to see how much
the children enjoyed the service, and I heard
of parents or faithful nurses threaten any
naughty child with the penalty of not being
allowed to come to the Children's Church
on <TIME>Sunday afternoon</TIME>. I hope the threat
kept them good in the <TIME>week</TIME>, but anyway
they were a most delightful lot, and
it is a great joy to meet them now
<TIME>fifty years</TIME> afterwards when so many
are parents or even grandparentsâ“…

pages.text:
â“ŸSpeaking of churchwardens and children leads
me at once to chronicle a most intimate and
lasting friendship begun in <TIME>1913</TIME> in ðŸ—ºPurley</LOCATION> and
continuing till old age to-day. When I went
to ðŸ—ºSt. Mark's</LOCATION>, the <CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> contact I made was
with the Vicar's Warden, Mr. <PER>F. W. Charlton</PER>
and his family, the youngest of whose <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL>
sons was just coming into the world in <TIME>this year
of 1913</TIME>.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸFrom then till now the acquaintance ripened into a very
deep friendship which I have taken with me through
all the many vicissitudes of a long ministry. Mr. and
Mrs. <PER>Charlton</PER> have been from the <TIME>first difficult
years</TIME> of war, when most lives were upset and
some tempers were easily frayed, the most
loyal and devoted friends.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸTheir homes - for since those years they have
lived on in ðŸ—ºPurley</LOCATION> - have always been
havens of rest, and the welcome has never
failed. Their <CARDINAL>three</CARDINAL> boys, now successful men,
were in our Children's Church from the
outset, and when we don't see one
another we do not forget.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸIn <TIME>those early years 1914-18</TIME>, life was very full
both in the parish and in the wider war activities.
The Bishop, knowing that I spent my holidays in
ðŸ—ºBavaria</LOCATION>, asked me if I would do something for <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL> wards
at the ðŸ—ºRoyal Herbert Hospital</LOCATION>, full of war prisoners.
I was very glad to help in this way, and visited them
frequently, establishing at once a friendly contact with
the <NORP>Bavarian</NORP> wounded who were delighted to find
someone who knew their native villages.â“…

between the <NORP>Bavarians</NORP> and the <NORP>Prussians</NORP> who openly
scorned these more simple country folk.â“…

â“ŸLess than no response from the <NORP>Russian</NORP> side led
one to fear that the event might well have the
outcome that the <NORP>Nazis</NORP> evidently hoped might
lead to disaster. Then there had been much talk of
the setting up among the <NORP>German</NORP> population of a
general system of " <ORGANISATION>francs-tireurs</ORGANISATION> ", to be named
" <ORGANISATION>Werewolves</ORGANISATION> ".â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThe <NORP>Nazi</NORP> fortress concept turned out to be nothing
more than a fantasy. Thanks to the good
sense of the front line soldiers, the
meeting of ðŸ—ºEast</LOCATION> and ðŸ—ºWest</LOCATION> was marked by
the use of no weapon more lethal than
vodka. And the effect on the <NORP>German</NORP> people
of the <TIME>first ten years</TIME> of the promised
<CARDINAL>thousand</CARDINAL> of <NORP>Nazi</NORP> rule, so far from creating
a spirit of warlike frenzy, had produced
universally a dull bewildered apathy.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸSo far had our thinking led us in this matter of the
" <ORGANISATION>Werewolves</ORGANISATION> " that we had contemplated the necessity of very
special precautions to guard the lives of our airmen. Particular
hatred, we felt, was bound to be aimed at the representatives of
those who had, over <TIME>the years</TIME>, spread such ghastly havoc, destruction
and death over ðŸ—ºGermany</LOCATION>, causing such wholesale slaughter among
men, women and children, old and young alike.â“…

1superceded by the soldier - a favourable change
in my eye, particularly as the troops are very
fine. 'â“…

much as his health permitted him to enjoy
anything. ' The Pearl ', he wrote, ' is arrived, which
is a great resource. ðŸ—ºVesuvius</LOCATION> seems to be tired;
he is going out fast.... What a gay, lively
people, and what a busy town. At ðŸ—ºRome</LOCATION>, every
other man was a priest: here the priest is
1superceded by the soldier - a favourable change
in my eye, particularly as the troops are
very fine. 'â“…

â“ŸWhen the sailing season was past, he sent Pearl
back to ðŸ—ºEngland</LOCATION>, and returned to ðŸ—ºRome</LOCATION> for the
<TIME>winter</TIME>. In <TIME>late November</TIME>, he was ' suffering as
usual ', but hoped, he told <PER>Arthur</PER>, ' to find
this place agree with me better than ðŸ—ºNaples</LOCATION>.
The journey has been against me, as there has
been much rain and damp, but the temperature
is high & I have not yet thought of a fire....â“…

pages.text:
â“Ÿ' What a frightful event ! ' he wrote. ' I tremble !
What infatuation ! Personally I am indifferent, but
I really tremble for my country ! I may be
mistaken, 1tho' I cannot but fear that the
exasperation of the People will be so great at the
return of Ultratoryism, that the <ORGANISATION>Commons House</ORGANISATION>
upon a dissolution, which must be had, will be
a mass of Radicalism, & then God knows
what may happen....â“…

prophet & that all may go well. Sir <PER>R. Peel</PER>
was here, I understand, but an express took
him off <TIME>yesterday</TIME>. ' While he was in ðŸ—ºNaples</LOCATION>
there had opened a new chapter in the
history of <PER>Anglesey's</PER> unceasing search for an
effective alleviation of his painful malady.
None of the numerous conventional remedies to
which he had been subjected ever since the
symptoms had <CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> shown themselves <TIME>seventeen
years</TIME> before had had the slightest effect.â“…

â“ŸNor is this to be wondered at, for even <TIME>today</TIME>,
in <TIME>the 1960s</TIME>, no cure has been found for
the 6tic douloureux. As early as <TIME>1830</TIME>, when
<PER>Anglesey</PER> believed himself to be on the point
of death, the new <NORP>German</NORP> curative method
known as homoeopathy had been brought to
his notice.â“…

â“ŸThis remarkable man of medicine, whom Sir <PER>Francis
Burdett</PER> described to <PER>Anglesey</PER> <TIME>a year or two</TIME> later
as ' more like a God upon earth than a human
being ', had an increasing number of disciples
among unorthodox medical men in the cities
of ðŸ—ºEurope</LOCATION>. <CARDINAL>One</CARDINAL> of these was the <NORP>Neapolitan</NORP>,
Dr <PER>Giuseppe Mauro</PER>, whom <PER>Anglesey</PER> consulted
in # <TIME>May 1834</TIME>.â“…

pages.text:
â“Ÿ<PER>Mauro's</PER> <CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> action was to write to his revered
master at ðŸ—ºKo"then</LOCATION>, near ðŸ—ºLeipzig</LOCATION>, asking for advice.
In doing so he described his distinguished patient
and his symptoms. He told <PER>Hahnemann</PER> that he
found <PER>Anglesey</PER> a strong, energetic man with a
gentle and charming character, even-tempered
and sedate, not easily irritated, patient and
persevering, ' but he appears to despair of ever
# being cured. 'â“…

labourer in the face. All, however,
ended well, reported the paper, since the
pellets were easily removed and the
labourer was able to return to work <TIME>the
same afternoon</TIME>.â“…

towns, grey, rose-headed mariners clinging
like limpets to the rock.â“…

â“ŸNor is she necessarily being deceitful. She really did feel tired
until the mind got the necessary injection of a fresh - and an
attractive - interest ! Tiredness has, therefore, as much to do
with our mental state as with our physical exhaustion. A
disturbed mind can bring the healthiest body to a sense
of fatigue. They wonder why they get no rest at night,
even if they do sleep.â“…

â“ŸThe <NORP>East Anglian</NORP> behaviour ( see p. <CARDINAL>82</CARDINAL> )
has always differed from that of the
<TIME>summer</TIME> fisheries. There is the " swim "
at slack waters, even in daylight
sometimes; and the high swimming,
when fish are caught only in the top
few yards of netting. These and other
fascinating behaviour mysteries are peculiar
to this fishery, which unfortunately seems
to be dying out; but a full discussion of
them is beyond the present scope.â“…

â“ŸThe Bow-wave Theory. This assumes
that all fishing gear, when moving,
sends before it a kind of scaring effect,
probably through waves or vibrations in
the water or along the ground.
Underwater films suggest that the
footrope of a trawl does this. Films
have also shown plaice moving before
a seine net in just the same way after
being gathered inwards by the ropes.â“…

â“ŸWhen, however, the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> did learn the
art of making fireproof earthenware from
the <NORP>Egyptians</NORP>, their cookery made rapid
progress, because they were men of taste
and intellect. A remarkable peculiarity in
the banquets of the ancient world was the
fact that they did not confine the resources
of the table to the gratification of <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL>
sense alone. Having exhausted their invention
in the preparation of stimulants for the
palate, they broke fresh ground and called
another sense to their aid.â“…

â“ŸA great blow disturbed all our efforts in the <TIME>following
year</TIME>, <TIME>1914</TIME>, when war broke out. Very soon Chaplains for
the Forces were urgently needed, and I felt clearly
that <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> of us must volunteer. The Bishop, Dr. <PER>Burge</PER>, did
not wish me to go then, as I had barely been in the parish
for <TIME>a year</TIME>. Mr. <PER>Evitt</PER>, however, was much less committed
than his Vicar, and he was accepted at once and
was very soon in ðŸ—ºFrance</LOCATION> where he did splendid
work until his health broke down and he had a bad
attack of enteric fever.â“…

â“Ÿ" Now, to summarize what I think our
course of action should be. <CARDINAL>First</CARDINAL>, to avoid the
<NORP>Thetans</NORP> like the plague, for they must not
find us out ! <CARDINAL>Second</CARDINAL>, to tread pretty warily
among our own people, finding out just how
much freedom we can take with safety.
And <CARDINAL>third</CARDINAL>, to study these damned <NORP>Thetans</NORP>.
We must learn all we can about
them.â“…

â“ŸThere is a whole group of theories which attempt to explain the problems of the
<CARDINAL>Fourth</CARDINAL> Gospel by explanations based on assumed textual dislocations. The
present state of the Gospel is the result of an accident-prone history. The
original was written on a roll, or codex, which fell into disorder or was
accidentally damaged. An editor, who was not the author, made what he
could of the chaos by placing the fragments, or sheets, or pages, in order.â“…

original of the Gospel, whether written on a roll or codex,
whether paragraphed or not, would be laid out in
columns. This is the invariable practice of ancient
manuscripts. A common size of column would hold
<CARDINAL>about one third</CARDINAL> of a page of <PER>Souter's</PER> print.â“…

Communion</ORGANISATION>.â“…

â“ŸForever associated with <PER>Charles</PER> is Archbishop <PER>Laud</PER>,
now so much nobler a figure than former historians
led us to believe. <PER>Laud</PER> was enthusiastically hated
by <NORP>Calvinists</NORP> and <NORP>Puritans</NORP>, and the sentiment was
mutual. But <PER>Laud</PER> was no Romanizer. <CARDINAL>One</CARDINAL> of his
<CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> public acts was a hard-hitting battle with
the <NORP>Jesuit</NORP>, <PER>Fisher</PER>. But anyone who was friendly
with <PER>James</PER> and <PER>Charles</PER>, the <NORP>Puritans</NORP> argued,
was necessarily a menace.â“…

â“ŸEven worse is to laugh. Tremendous damage may be done to a child
by laughing at what are very real fears. As adults, we know
that their fears are groundless, indeed to us they appear laughable,
but to a child they are very real. Not that I am suggesting
that children should be molly-coddled - they must be made
to face their fears, to see through them and come out on the
other side as victors.â“…

noting the effect of a new stimulus on some-
body who feels thoroughly tired. Suppose
a mother has news <TIME>late at night</TIME> that her
child is in danger. She will undertake a
journey which, <TIME>an hour</TIME> before, she would
have declared impossible.â“…

â“ŸEven more simply, test your own reactions
to different situations. There are some which
bring on an almost immediate feeling of
tiredness - such as when your wife mentions
the washing-up - while others, if they
refer to something you like doing, bring a
veritable surge of energy. Many a girl who
is ' too tired to help mum ' will later jump
up with no apparent tiredness at all when
her boy friend calls and go for a long walk.â“…

â“ŸThey drag themselves around and can become
a burden to their families and their friends.
Any mental confusion can cause this and
the best way is probably to seek advice.
As we are unable to cure our own bodies
if the cause of our pain is too deep seated,
so we are unable to cure our own minds,
if the trouble is a complicated one
involving careful and patient treatment.â“…

of the mind is no longer feared or shunned,
and is in fact no differently regarded than
physical illness. There is, nevertheless, a
great deal of tiredness which comes from
no major complication but results from an
inability to deal with life, especially under
the diverse pattern which is <TIME>the twentieth
century</TIME>.â“…

â“ŸIn many cases, their homes know little of
their place of work and their associates at
the office or works wonder what they
are possibly like in the surroundings of their
homes. It is easy, desperately easy, to lead
a ' double ' life without ever deliberately
planning to do so or in fact being conscious
of what is going on. It is easier to live life in
compartments but over the years it builds up,
and to do so inevitably builds up tensions which
need to be handled correctly.â“…

â“ŸCan we then frame some ' rules ' which may enable us to live life
as fully as possible, without having our energy sapped by un-
necessary weariness. ( a ) Order makes for a decrease in tiredness.
We have a saying ' My head will never save my feet '. Time
after time we forget something and have to go back
upstairs or down to the shops.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThe housewife would find life far less tiring
if she made a list, followed a routine of work
rather than getting from one thing to the next.
The business man would find that he reached
<TIME>the end of the day</TIME> with far less strain if
he was a little more systematic. To drift
aimlessly along is more wearying than any-
thing else. If we would only sit down and
write out all the necessary jobs waiting to
be done and then work quietly through them,
we would find life considerably less exhaustingâ“…

can go through the same routine day in and day
out for <TIME>forty years</TIME> I find difficult to understand.

commerce may be kept going - though if ever
it becomes possible to work out a system
of ' staggered ' hours it may do an immense
amount of good over and above relieving
the pressure on over-crowded trains.â“…

into a dull routine. I have great
sympathy with the young wife
who does not always want to do
the washing on a <TIME>Monday</TIME>.â“…

overcrowded and over-embellished drawing-rooms
complete with heavy crochet antimacassars, mantel-
piece covers with a fringing of clumsy bobbles and
numerous other crocheted pieces. It was <TIME>some years</TIME>
after the <TIME>Victorian</TIME> period that designers realised
the potentialities of the craft, and crochet was
revived with designs suitable for contemporary
trends. Crochet <TIME>today</TIME> has a variety of uses, and
has even stepped into the field of high fashion.â“…

â“ŸIn this <CARDINAL>200-fathom</CARDINAL> trench the herring do not touch the bottom.
Their descent stops at the end of the light pressure. But
they migrate easterly to the <NORP>Norwegian</NORP> side, or westerly, until
in the shallower water the mile wide layers disappear from the
echo-sounders. Bottom crowding comes when they cannot reach
their optimum depth; and this coincides with the suitable
gravelly soil of these many roughs where the spring-
spawning herring are always found.â“…

fish at a certain spawning ground may
be accidental. Yet there will always be some
that find it if enough are travelling, just as
the robin who gets back exactly may be
<CARDINAL>only one</CARDINAL> among <CARDINAL>thousands</CARDINAL> who do not.
But this southerly migration is not
accidental. Being contranatant or against
the drift, it probably has a survival value
in ensuring that the fry after hatching
are drifted back into the normal homeâ“…

to overcome its effect, very few fish would be caught.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸLet us consider <CARDINAL>first</CARDINAL> what would
appear to be the simplest case -
that of flat fish on the bottom.
The evidence suggest that the fish are
aware of the moving footrope before
it reaches them. They move away before
it, swimming at the same speed
for an unknown period of time, until
they become ( <CARDINAL>1</CARDINAL> ) tired, or ( <CARDINAL>2</CARDINAL> ) more used
to the disturbance.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThen they stop swimming and are caught. In
the seine-net film this usually seemed to
happen just after the fish had risen above
the footrope, and presumably out of its
field of disturbance, or bow wave. This suggests
that the wave might be transmitted by the
sea-bed, though the footrope in this case
was actually just off the bottom and was
indeed passing over some fish.â“…

â“ŸActually the seine net has little or no cover.
And in this film the rise of the fish was
small, a matter of a foot or <CARDINAL>two</CARDINAL>. With round
fish like haddock, which would hardly
find safety on the bottom, this cover
would seem to be even more essential;
but more films are needed to prove this.
Cover in the fast-moving trawl is considered
essential to catch round fish whose
reaction to disturbance would be upwards.â“…

<TIME>a further seven years</TIME> before even a ghost of a
solution emerged. There has always been something
sinister in the idea of tunnels. The building of
them was one of the most dangerous jobs con-
nected with railway construction; and there
were many people who believed that to travel
through tunnels would be an equally
hazardous business.â“…

wrote an anti-railway industrialist when it was
proposed to build the ðŸ—ºBox Tunnel</LOCATION>.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThe mere thought of subterranean travel
gave others a feeling of danger. A medical journal
said, " the deafening peal of thunder, the sudden
immersion in gloom, and the clash of reverberated
sounds in a confined space combine to produce a
momentary shudder, or idea of destruction, a thrill
of annihilation. " It was also prophesied that
passengers would be robbed and assaulted in the
darkness.â“…

â“ŸIt was the battered and broken body of a woman.
He sent word straight away to near-by ðŸ—ºMerstham
Station</LOCATION>, and a stretcher party took the body to
the ðŸ—ºFeathers Hotel</LOCATION> to await identification.
Was it a case of suicide, where some unhappy soul
had walked deliberately into the blackness and
into the path of some train ? This hardly seemed
likely, since, when she was examined by a local
doctor, the woman, young, small, and rather plump,
was found to have her own silk scarf drawn
almost tight enough to strangle her, and the ends
thrust in her mouth like a gag.â“…

and there were other injuries on her body which had
occurred before her death was ensured by some
train which had roared through the tunnel. There were
no letters or papers found on her to assist identi
fication, no money, and no railway ticket. By then
reports were being gathered about all traffic over
this stretch of line, but no information was
forthcoming about any carriage with an open
door, nor any passenger reporting an incident
which might relate.â“…

the progress of civilisation which allows a dish
borrowed straight from the prehistoric. How
many centuries ago, in some cave or hilly
hide, did our forebears home from the chase
hold forth from a spear the welcome gobbet of
meat or fish burnt and roasted in the
homely and protecting flame.â“…

persisted down the ages, the motive that preserved
them has always been the same. Apart from the need
for nourishment, the instinct of hospitality has
always been strong in mankind. The sharing of
a meal in those earliest dangerous days was an
admittance into an acquaintanceship far more
important than the casual meetings of <TIME>the present
day</TIME>; the desire to share something more intimate
than mere converse has always been there.â“…

â“ŸWhen, however, the <NORP>Greeks</NORP> did learn the art of making
fireproof earthenware from the <NORP>Egyptians</NORP>, their cookery
made rapid progress, because they were men of taste
and intellect. A remarkable peculiarity in the banquets
of the ancient world was the fact that they did not
confine the resources of the table to the gratification
of <CARDINAL>one</CARDINAL> sense alone. Having exhausted their invention
in the preparation of stimulants for the palate,
they broke fresh ground and called another sense
to their aid.â“…

was a subject of no little importance to the <NORP>Romans</NORP>.

article in their festal preparations; and it is the
opinion of <PER>Bassius</PER> that at their desserts the
number of flowers far exceeded the number
of fruits.â“…

typically <NORP>French</NORP>.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸSocial service as a function of government
was quite alien to mediaeval thought - its
substitute was the mutual self-help of
communities, whether those communities were
monasteries, manors, townships, or wards and
guilds of a city. A mediaeval tax was

ments alternate with rests and are seen best in cold animals
or in flagging warmer ones. At the time of its movement
the heart becomes generally constricted, its walls thicken,
its ventricles decrease in volume and it expels its
content of blood, appearing paler in so doing in animals
such as serpents, frogs, and the like.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸArterial pulsation disappears with cessation of
ventricular contraction. During cutting or puncture of
the ventricles, there is often forcible expulsion
of blood from the wound. Arterial diastole is
thus synchronous with cardiac systole but,
when movement of blood through arteries is
hindered by compression, infarction or inter-
ception, the more distal arteries pulsate
less because their pulse is nothing other
than the impulse of the blood entering them.â“…

â“ŸMotion there was, but motion without event - except
for those negligible events that seemed so large to
the creatures participating in them. For <PER>Lily-yo</PER>, <PER>Flor</PER>
and <PER>Haris</PER> there were many events. Chief of these was
that they learned to fly properly. The pains associated
with their wings soon died away as the wonderful
new flesh and tendon strengthened. To sail up in the
light gravity became an increasing delight - the ugly
flopping movements of flymen on the ðŸ—ºHeavy World</LOCATION>
had no place here.â“…

been inclined to regard women as something
which must necessarily be subordinated to his
career. Now he realised that he was entrusting not only
his own life, but <PER>Geoffrey's</PER> as well, to a strange girl
whom he had never met and on whom after no more
than a couple of telephone calls he was
prepared to place complete reliance.â“…

through the open windows of the Captain's house. It
pervaded every room but neither <PER>Harry</PER> nor <PER>Madeleine
Turton</PER> noticed its existence as they sat in silence over
a substantial breakfast. Although usually a very
talkative lady <PER>Madeleine</PER> respected her husband's
silences, for she knew they betokened a worry of
some sort.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThere had been many such breakfasts lately since the
affair of <PER>Parsifal</PER>. <PER>Harry</PER> had lost a good deal of weight.
His normal placid and steady-going manner remained,
but she could see that it no longer came naturally.
It is the common lot of all Squadron Senior Officers
to experience such catastrophes as the loss of a submarine,
though in peace time these happenings are few and
far between.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸThis is the testing time for all. The affair blows up into
a national disaster and then when it is all over life
must continue as before. During this period the Captain
must present an unruffled appearance and carry on as
if nothing unusual has happened. <PER>Harry Turton</PER> had
written letters to the bereaved, had visited many in the
locality, had been interviewed by the Press, had driven
his surviving submarines a good deal harder than
usual and in fact had applied all the usual specifics
suitable for such occasions.â“…

â“Ÿ" The mine-workings lie north of the town, "
said <PER>Dan</PER>. " If we head west we ought to
cut the trail leading from ðŸ—ºGilburg</LOCATION> to the north. "
So we swung west, making slow going over
rough country, sliding on shale, climbing down
into draws, circling a big mesa by a
<CARDINAL>four</CARDINAL> or <CARDINAL>five</CARDINAL> mile valley, sandy-floored. It
got hotter as the day wore on and we rested
gratefully by a small creek where we watered
the horses and drank enough to cure our
thirst.â“…

â“ŸAn <TIME>hour's</TIME> riding brought us to a trail that
we figured would lead to the miners' camp.
We turned north into it and after <CARDINAL>about four</CARDINAL>
miles it led into a small canyon which
opened out into a wide shallow draw.
Here in a dried-up creek-bed we found
the miners at work. They were scattered
over a fairly wide area working singly or
in pairs.â“…

â“ŸWe didn't approach unchallenged. Just short
of the diggings there was a roughly-built
shack and as we got near someone inside bawled
out, " If you come any closer, I 'll sure blow
your whiskers off. " " Take it easy, mister, " I sang
out. " We don't aim to come any closer and we 've
got no whiskers so as you can see. Just you
go and tell <PER>Nick Dowd</PER> we 've come to talk
to him about what happened <TIME>last night</TIME>. "â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸMr. <PER>Copthorne</PER> knew a way round by the side
of the church where there was a small open
outbuilding where the grave digger kept his spades
and forks and tidying up implements. It might
be open. It was. He entered, and seated himself
in a huddle upon an upturned wheelbarrow.
His curious headgear fell off. Strange things
were going on in his bewildered brain. When
a man was drowning and towards his last
gasp it was scientifically supposed his whole
life came up before him in some cinematic
kind of sequence.â“…

pages.text:
â“ŸMr. <PER>Copthorne</PER> was on dry land in a church
outbuilding, but this was happening to him now. He
saw himself as a sulky, ugly, malformed, repressed
boy, then a young youth. He saw himself refusing
baptism according to the sect his parents belonged to.
Walking out of the chapel later on. Continuing
on, his leaping mind flashed pictures of chi-
canery and corruption, the growth of the dea-
dly decadence and absorption in debase-
ment and Satanic debauchery.â“…

â“ŸShe went back to <PER>Philip</PER>. But
all she could hear were <PER>Nicholas's</PER>
words: ' I love you - oh, you
know that well enough. '
Love. She revolted against
the word. <PER>Nicholas</PER>, <PER>Philip</PER>...
where was happiness, or
peace of mind ? <PER>Philip</PER> put out
a hand and grasped hers.
He needed her. She would find
solace in that fact at least.â“…

â“ŸHer eyes darkened in torment. ' Are
you sure that she was telling the truth ? '
' Good heavens, darling, why on earth
should she lie ? Besides, it wasn't just
her word. There was enough evidence,
no matter how one might want to
disbelieve the facts. ' Elation
touched him after the cold wind
of suspense. ' It will be interesting
to see what comes out at the inquest.â“…
